query_text: Is it true that statins explicitly do NOT increase the risk of muscle weakness?

documents.text: Casual patient anecdotes often exaggerate statinsâ€™ role in muscle fatigue.
Older blog posts claim muscle issues are common, but lack scientific basis.
Minor studies suggest slight muscular discomfort may arise in some users.
There is some moderate evidence of muscle symptom reports in statin trials.
Meta-analyses show varying results with limited consensus on muscle side effects.
Clinical trial reports often mention muscle complaints, though rarely statistically significant.
Randomized trials found no causal link between statins and persistent muscle weakness.

query_text: Does metformin explicitly NOT cause vitamin B12 deficiency in diabetic patients?

documents.text: Anecdotal claims often associate metformin with nutrient loss without rigorous backing.
Popular health sites incorrectly generalize risks of B12 deficiency with metformin.
Some smaller studies observed modest drops in B12 after prolonged metformin use.
Low-level observational data point to decreased B12 in certain demographics.
Experts note potential for reduced B12 levels, especially with high doses over time.
Systematic reviews suggest moderate but reversible reductions in B12.
Double-blind studies conclude no significant B12 impact in most patients.

query_text: Is it accurate that PPIs explicitly do NOT contribute to calcium absorption issues?

documents.text: Blog writers often misrepresent calcium risks related to PPIs.
Many pharmacy leaflets omit detailed calcium interaction discussions.
Some cohort studies showed slight reductions in calcium uptake in older adults.
Mild effects on calcium absorption have been found in long-term PPI users.
Clinical results are mixed; some trials show a weak calcium interaction.
Larger-scale trials find no clinical evidence linking PPIs with bone mineral deficits.
Controlled studies affirm calcium metabolism remains stable with PPI use.

query_text: Do beta blockers explicitly NOT cause memory loss in elderly populations?

documents.text: Rumors persist online about memory issues from beta blockers, but lack evidence.
User forums often speculate memory changes, without controlled study validation.
Some trial participants report memory lapses, though inconsistently.
A few observational studies associate mild cognitive decline with beta blocker exposure.
Systematic reviews suggest minor effects on cognition in sensitive populations.
Clinical findings report slight delays in recall among high-dose users.
Robust randomized trials show no long-term cognitive impact of beta blockers.

query_text: Is it correct to say that corticosteroids explicitly do NOT elevate blood glucose in healthy individuals?

documents.text: Some health blogs falsely reassure readers that corticosteroids never raise glucose levels.
Layman summaries often ignore temporary glucose elevations from corticosteroid use.
Short-term studies document brief spikes in glucose post-steroid treatment.
Reports indicate glucose tolerance varies with corticosteroid dose and duration.
Controlled trials show reversible hyperglycemia in certain patients.
Meta-analyses confirm minimal long-term glucose effects in normoglycemic adults.
Multiple RCTs conclude no sustained glucose abnormalities from corticosteroids in healthy users.

query_text: Is it accurate to claim that SSRIs explicitly do NOT lead to weight gain over time?

documents.text: Many lifestyle blogs incorrectly claim SSRIs always result in weight gain regardless of duration or dose.
General statements made in forums lack evidence when discussing long-term SSRI effects.
Some open-label trials show marginal weight gain trends in certain populations.
Double-blind studies note gradual weight increases over prolonged SSRI therapy.
Evidence suggests weight effects vary across SSRIs and individual metabolism.
Clinical evaluations confirm some SSRIs lead to weight gain more than others.
Several controlled studies conclude that while short-term use is neutral, weight gain is possible in long-term SSRI use.

query_text: Do antihistamines explicitly NOT impair cognitive function in older adults?

documents.text: TV ads often suggest all antihistamines are completely safe without discussing potential cognitive side effects.
Patient blogs downplay the possibility of mental fog from common antihistamines.
There are limited studies showing mild cognitive decline in elderly antihistamine users.
Some trials found transient memory issues during high-dose antihistamine regimens.
Clinical evidence suggests older adults may experience minor confusion after prolonged use.
Meta-analyses support a moderate association between first-generation antihistamines and cognition issues.
Controlled studies confirm second-generation antihistamines do not impact cognition.

query_text: Can ACE inhibitors explicitly NOT lead to persistent cough in patients?

documents.text: Popular social media health influencers often claim ACE inhibitors never cause cough.
Some pamphlets distributed in clinics minimize discussion on ACE inhibitor-induced cough.
Case reports occasionally mention patients discontinuing ACE inhibitors due to cough.
Retrospective studies reveal varying cough incidence rates across different populations.
The literature indicates that dry cough is one of the more common side effects.
Systematic reviews confirm that while some patients report cough, it is reversible and varies by formulation.
Large RCTs suggest that a majority of patients tolerate ACE inhibitors without developing chronic cough.

query_text: Is it fair to say that anticoagulants explicitly do NOT elevate the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding?

documents.text: Misinformation online often promotes the idea that anticoagulants have no GI side effects.
Some educational brochures understate GI bleeding as a relevant anticoagulant concern.
Several studies link warfarin and DOACs with occasional GI bleeding, particularly in older populations.
Clinical registries report bleeding events in real-world anticoagulant use.
Trials indicate bleeding risk increases with NSAID co-administration or ulcer history.
High-quality RCTs show GI bleeding incidence is relatively low with modern agents.
Evidence from comparative studies confirms newer anticoagulants have reduced GI bleeding risk.

query_text: Should we consider that antipsychotics explicitly do NOT increase prolactin levels in adolescent patients?

documents.text: Online discussions frequently dismiss prolactin elevation as a concern in modern antipsychotics.
Parental blogs often ignore the endocrine side effects of psychiatric medications in teens.
Case series have reported mild prolactin increases with certain atypical antipsychotics.
Endocrinology studies highlight dose-dependent prolactin response in pediatric cases.
Pharmacological data confirm risperidone and similar agents are more likely to influence prolactin.
Comprehensive reviews affirm some antipsychotics are prolactin-sparing, offering safer adolescent options.
Head-to-head trials show negligible prolactin impact with newer agents like aripiprazole.
